### H. Africa Digital Financial Inclusion Facility (ADFI)

- **Mandate**: Pan-African
- **Target**: Women and Small/Medium Enterprises
- **Focus**: Strategic and catalytic investments in DFS ecosystem
- **2025 Deadlines**: May-June 2025 for various components

  - Financial service providers
  - DFS capacity building

## Technology Vendors - Market Intelligence

### Top 5 Core Banking Solutions for African MFIs

#### 1. Temenos
**Market Position**: Leading enterprise solution

**Recent African Implementations:**
- **ASA International** (2024): Deploying across Ghana, Tanzania, Kenya (Azure Cloud), first live summer 2024
  - Client Profile: 2.3M clients across 13 countries, Amsterdam/Dhaka HQ
  - Focus: Small socially responsible loans, majority to women
- **VisionFund International** (2024): Ghana, Tanzania, Zambia - go-live August 2024
- **Barko (South Africa)**: Digital bank launch using Temenos (announced 2024)

**Key Features:**
- Progressive modernization
- Cloud transition support
- Extensibility and customization
- Strong compliance and governance

**Source**: [Temenos Success Stories](https://www.temenos.com/sector/microfinance/)

---

#### 2. Mambu
**Market Position**: Agile SaaS platform

**African Client:**
- **Carbon Finance** (Pan-African): Long-standing customer
  - Started as lending platform in Nigeria
  - Received banking license in 2020
  - Now full-service, customer-centric bank

**Key Features:**
- Exceptional flexibility and scalability
- Rapid market adaptation
- Customizable products
- Seamless integrations

**Source**: [Mambu Africa Insights](https://mambu.com/en/insights-hub/articles/the-fintech-opportunity-in-africa)

---

#### 3. Musoni
**Market Position**: Africa-focused MFI specialist

**Stats:**
- **90+ MFIs** using Musoni across Africa
- **350,000+ end clients** served
- **Geographic Reach**: Malawi, Zambia, Zimbabwe, and others

**Key Features:**
- Cloud-based microfinance software
- Efficient loan and savings management
- Mobile banking integration
- Reliable data analytics
- Built on Apache Fineract core

**Source**: [Musoni System](https://musonisystem.com/)

**Award**: MLF Zambia (Musoni client) won MFI 2023 Top Impact Award - Africa

---

#### 4. Apache Fineract
**Market Position**: Open source standard

**Origin**: Created at Mifos Initiative (Grameen Foundation spin-off, Dr. Muhammad Yunus)

**Adoption:**
- Used by Musoni as core component (90 MFIs)
- Foundation for multiple African implementations

**Key Features:**
- Open source (Apache Foundation)
- Core banking as a platform
- Reliable, robust, affordable
- Supports any organizational type or delivery channel
- Flexible product/service/methodology support
- Integrated real-time accounting
- Social and financial reporting

**Cost Advantage**: 25% lower than brick-and-mortar branch operations

**Source**: [Apache Fineract](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/incubator/FineractProposal)

---

#### 5. Oracle FLEXCUBE
**Market Position**: Enterprise-grade, 20+ years in Africa

**African Stats:**
- **100+ banks** in Africa using FLEXCUBE
- 20+ years powering African banks

**Recent Implementation:**
- **Housing Finance Bank** (East Africa): June 2024 go-live with version 14.5
- **LAPO Microfinance Bank** (Nigeria): Largest MFI (4M customers)
  - Also implementing Oracle Banking Digital Experience (OBDX)
  - Oracle Banking Payments (OBP)
- **Zenith Bank** (Nigeria): Migrating from Phoenix to FLEXCUBE (2024)

**Key Features:**
- Comprehensive microfinance module
- Retail, corporate, SME, Islamic banking support
- Flexible environment
- Faster product definition
- Better risk insight and reporting

**Source**: [Oracle FLEXCUBE Africa](https://www.oracle.com/africa/financial-services/banking/flexcube/)

## Historical Analysis

### Market Winners & Patterns

#### Implementation Partners
**JMR Infotech**: Successfully implemented Oracle FLEXCUBE for Housing Finance Bank (June 2024) - demonstrates value of specialized implementation partners

**Software Group (Kenya)**: Won contract with BRAC Uganda Bank Ltd for Agency Banking platform (2021) - shows Kenya-based tech firms winning regional deals

---

### Typical Evaluation Criteria (Based on Market Intelligence)

#### 1. Technical Requirements
- **Microfinance-specific functionality**: Loan management, savings, group lending
- **Digital channels**: Mobile banking, USSD, agency banking
- **Integration capabilities**: Payment systems, credit bureaus, mobile money
- **Scalability**: Cloud-based, able to handle rapid client growth
- **Compliance**: Regulatory reporting, audit trails, KYC/AML
- **Data analytics**: Credit scoring, risk management, business intelligence

#### 2. Commercial Considerations
- **Total Cost of Ownership**: License + implementation + ongoing support
- **Price benchmarks**: $2M disclosed for World Bank Mozambique project (though canceled)
- **Pricing models**: Perpetual license vs. SaaS subscription
- **Local support**: In-country presence, training, helpdesk

#### 3. Vendor Qualifications
- **African experience**: Proven implementations in similar markets
- **References**: Working systems in comparable MFIs
- **Financial stability**: Vendor longevity and R&D investment
- **Technology stack**: Modern architecture, API-first, cloud-ready

#### 4. Local Content & Partnerships
- **Kenya**: 40% budget set-aside for local goods/services (Presidential directive, 2015)
- **Nigeria**: Majority local ownership (>50%) for tender preferences
- **South Africa**: Various designated industries have minimum local content thresholds
- **Sierra Leone**: 50% local ownership threshold; 5% price preference for local bidders

**Source**: [COMESA Regional Local Content Policy](https://www.comesa.int/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/COMESA-Regional-LC-Policy-Guidelines-Final-ENG.pdf)

---

### Procurement Cycle Timing

**Typical Timeline**: 12-24 months from tender to go-live

**Phases:**
1. **Tender Preparation**: 2-3 months (RFP development, approvals)
2. **Bidding Period**: 2-3 months (proposal preparation, clarifications)
3. **Evaluation**: 2-4 months (technical evaluation, demos, due diligence)
4. **Contract Negotiation**: 1-2 months
5. **Implementation**: 6-12 months (configuration, data migration, training, testing)
6. **Go-Live**: Phased rollout (pilot branches → full deployment)

**Example**: Housing Finance Bank Oracle FLEXCUBE implementation completed June 2024 - project likely started 2023

---

### Common Disqualification Reasons

Based on procurement best practices:
1. **Incomplete documentation**: Missing required company certifications, references
2. **Insufficient African experience**: No proven implementations in similar markets
3. **Non-compliance with specifications**: Proposed solution doesn't meet functional requirements
4. **Financial concerns**: Insufficient financial capacity, unclear pricing
5. **Local content shortfalls**: Failure to meet local ownership or sourcing requirements
6. **Technical deficiencies**: Inability to demonstrate required integrations, scalability
7. **Late submission**: Missing tender deadlines

---

### Price Ranges (Indicative)

**Based on market intelligence:**
- **Tier 4 Micro/Community MFIs** (<10,000 clients): $50K-$200K
- **Tier 3 Regional MFIs** (10K-100K clients): $200K-$500K
- **Tier 2 National MFIs** (100K-500K clients): $500K-$2M
- **Tier 1 Large MFIs** (500K+ clients): $2M-$10M+

**NMB Tanzania context**: 2.3M customers, $2M+ range likely

**Note**: SaaS models may have lower upfront costs but higher long-term costs

## Upcoming Pipeline (2025-2026)

### High-Probability Opportunities

#### 1. Ethiopia - MFI Sector Digitization
- **Driver**: Ethio Telecom cloud-based core banking initiative (2025)
- **Target**: Multiple microfinance institutions and SACCOs
- **Policy**: Digital Ethiopia 2025 strategy
- **Status**: Rollout phase beginning
- **Opportunity Type**: Individual MFI implementations, platform integrations
- **Probability**: HIGH
- **Source**: [IT News Africa](https://www.itnewsafrica.com/2025/06/ethio-telecom-launches-cloud-based-core-banking-for-ethiopias-microfinance-sector/)

#### 2. Nigeria - CBN Microfinance Sector Upgrade
- **Driver**: CBN + Inlaks core banking solution (announced March 2025)
- **Target**: Nigeria's 900+ microfinance banks
- **Market Size**: ₦2.8 trillion in assets (Q2 2024), 91.3% growth YoY
- **Context**: CBN revoked 179 MFB licenses in 2023 for non-compliance - survivors need to upgrade
- **Capital Requirements**: N200M-N5B depending on tier
- **Opportunity Type**: Individual MFI implementations, add-on modules
- **Probability**: MEDIUM-HIGH
- **Timeline**: 2025-2026
- **Source**: [Fintech Futures](https://www.fintechfutures.com/core-banking-technology/new-core-banking-system-for-nigeria-s-microfinance-banks)

#### 3. ARIA Countries - Guinea and Togo (New 2024-2025)
- **Driver**: BII/Proparco/FMO expansion of ARIA program
- **Target**: MFIs and SACCOs in Guinea and Togo
- **Opportunity Type**: Technology infrastructure for financial inclusion projects
- **Probability**: MEDIUM
- **Timeline**: 2025-2026
- **Source**: [BII Press Release](https://www.bii.co.uk/en/news-insight/news/british-international-investment-is-joined-by-proparco-and-fmo-to-expand-the-reach-of-the-africa-resilience-investment-accelerator-aria-across-the-continent/)

#### 4. ASA International - Ghana, Tanzania, Kenya Expansion
- **Status**: Deployment moving forward (announced 2024)
- **Solution**: Temenos on Azure Cloud
- **Timeline**: First country live summer 2024, others following
- **Size**: 2.3M clients across 13 countries
- **Opportunity Type**: Integration partners, add-on services, training
- **Probability**: HIGH (deployment confirmed)
- **Source**: [Temenos Success Story](https://www.temenos.com/success-story/asa-international-success-story/)

#### 5. VisionFund International - Ghana, Tanzania, Zambia
- **Status**: Go-live due August 2024 (may have completed)
- **Solution**: Temenos
- **Opportunity Type**: Post-implementation services, integrations
- **Probability**: Follow-up opportunities (implementation likely complete)
- **Source**: [Temenos Success Story](https://www.temenos.com/success-story/visionfund-international-success-story/)
